docs.lead_paragraph: DR. MICHAEL MYERS, an internist in upstate New York, has all too often heard the complaints about expensive prescription drugs from elderly patients living on fixed incomes. So several years ago, he devised a cost-containment plan for about two dozen patients, most of whom lacked prescription drug coverage. Because many drugs cost the same for each tablet regardless of dosage, he suggested that certain higher-dose pills could be cut in half, resulting in significant savings over time.

headline.main: To Make a Pill More Affordable, Cut It in Half

docs.abstract: Many people, especially retirees with chronic ilnesses, have long resorted to splitting higher dosage pills, which often cost same as lower dosage ones, to help control escalating drug prices; some doctors advise practice, which has become increasingly institutionalized in recent years; some managed care companies have voluntary programs for splitting pills; critics cite potential problems; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the joys of retirement, in addition to sleeping in, is having time and energy for our friends. As during youth, we find that pain shared is pain reduced, while joy shared is joy enhanced. Yet during the big clump of our middle years, while career and parenthood were making their toughest demands on us, we gave our friends short, if any, shrift. Part of our latter-day talk with friends covers health. (''If an elder wakes up in the morning and something doesn't hurt, it means he died in the night.'')

headline.main: After the Kids, Careers and Craziness, There's Time for Old Friends

docs.abstract: June Bingham article cites having time and energy for friends as one of joys of retirement; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For a year, whenever Phillip Van Hooser traveled for speaking engagements, he ate the same item -- a turkey sandwich -- for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Mr. Van Hooser, 47, who owns a consulting firm in Princeton, Ky., did not have a food fetish; rather, he had inflammatory bowel disease, a disorder characterized by inflammation of the colon that required him to be near a bathroom during flare-ups. He found that the bland sandwich posed the least stress to his digestive system while he was on the road, which was (and is) more than half of the time. In November 2000, because his illness has no cure, he took a drastic step and had his colon surgically removed.

headline.main: Business Trips Can Be Hazardous to Your Health

docs.abstract: Article on various maladies that can pose problem during business trip; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare will soon publish detailed information comparing the prices of most prescription drugs, shining a bright light on some of the biggest secrets in the health care industry. Economists and federal officials say the information, intended to help Medicare beneficiaries, could also be immensely useful to other consumers, as well as to private insurers and employers who provide drug coverage to employees and retirees.

headline.main: Medicare Web Site to Provide Comparative Data on Retail Prices of Prescription Medicines

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the growing anxiety of several national Roman Catholic leaders, Senator John Kerry took communion here on Sunday at Easter services at the Paulist Center, a nontraditional church that describes itself as ''a worship community of Christians in the Roman Catholic tradition'' and which attracts people drawn to its dedication to ''family religious education and social justice.'' Mr. Kerry's decision to receive communion amounts to a challenge to several prominent Catholic bishops, who have become increasingly exasperated with politicians who are Catholic but who deviate from Catholic teaching.

headline.main: Kerry Attends Easter Services and Receives Holy Communion

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, takes communion at Easter services at Paulist Center in Boston; this amounts to challenge to several prominent Catholic bishops who are exasperated with politicans who are Catholic but who deviate from Catholic teaching; United States Conference of Catholic Bishops has task force studying how church should treat Catholic politicians like Kerry, who say they are personally opposed to abortion but support abortion rights legislation; some members of task force have suggested withholding communion from such politicians; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Salt Lake City announced last week that they had dropped charges of homicide against a woman who delayed a Cesarean section despite doctors' advice that it was necessary to save the lives of her twins. It was a step in the right direction, but the decision to criminalize the woman's choice -- one of her twins was later delivered stillborn, the other survived with complications, and the mother has pleaded guilty to child endangerment -- was wrong from the start. Not because it violated a patient's general right to privacy or a woman's specific right to make her own choices about reproduction (though it did). The charge was disturbing because it implied that the medical establishment can predict with certainty the best course of action for a fetus in distress. It cannot. In March 2002, when I was about 25 weeks pregnant, I had a severe case of pregnancy-related hypertension called pre-eclampsia. Like the woman in Utah, I went to the emergency room, where a sonogram revealed that my baby was in distress. My doctor recommended an immediate C-section, saying it was ''his best chance.'' The sonogram also showed that the baby would weigh about two and a half pounds. Unlike the woman in Utah, I took my doctor's advice.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Rebecca Johnson says prosecutors in Salt Lake City are right to drop homicide charges against woman who delayed Caesarean section despite doctors' advice that it was necessary; says homicide charge implied that medical establishment can always predict with certainty best course of action for fetus in distress, which it cannot; says record for ultrasound technology is mixed when it comes to identifying defects or predicting fetal weight; relates her experiece in agreeing to Caesarean section on doctor's advice, only to have her baby die four days later; says medicine cannot yet fix everything that can go wrong inside womb (M)
docs.snippet: Prosecutors in Salt Lake City announced last week that they had dropped charges of homicide against a woman who delayed a Cesarean section despite doctors' advice that it was necessary to save the lives of her twins. It was a step in the right...

docs.lead_paragraph: The rapid proliferation of suburban big-box stores hit a pronounced bump when Wal-Mart failed in an aggressive effort to build at least 130,000 square feet to sell everything from clothing to car tires in suburban Los Angeles. The world's largest retailer spent $1 million on a ballot initiative and a charm offensive, but residents weren't buying. This was more than the familiar battle between superstores and Main Street shopkeepers fearful of competition. With superstores now ubiquitous, the corporations that build them have been grabbing for increasingly inappropriate parcels of land to continue their expansion. The results of the vote in Inglewood, Calif., a community of 113,000 mostly black and Hispanic residents, showed that a much broader slice of the community than the owners of mom-and-pop hardware stores disapproved.

headline.main: In California, Wal-Mart Hits a Wall

docs.abstract: Editorial on failure of Wal-Mart's $1-million ballot initiative and charm offensive to convince people of Inglewood, California, to welcome superstore; points out that customers love low prices, until they take closer look at real costs, from low wages and benefits to driving out local stores

docs.lead_paragraph: Vineeta Vijayaraghavan was married yesterday to Thomas James DeLong. Pandit Sri Krishna Bhatta, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Swedenborg Chapel in Cambridge, Mass. Ms. Vijayaraghavan, 32, will continue to use her name. She is a consultant at Katzenbach Partners, a management consulting firm in New York. She is also the author of ''Motherland,'' a novel about a 15-year-old girl in India (Soho Press, 2001). She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard, where she also received an M.B.A.

docs.lead_paragraph: MANY of the headlines and television teasers about the Medicare trustees' annual report on March 23 were downright scary: ''Medicare Headed Toward Bankruptcy,'' ''Report Predicts Bankruptcy for Medicare by 2019'' and ''Medicare Could Go Broke by 2019.'' There was only one problem. They weren't true. Or, to be more precise, such warnings were a ''distortion and a disservice'' and ''totally inaccurate,'' according to Robert M. Hayes, president of the Medicare Rights Center, a nonprofit organization that helps people with Medicare problems. John L. Palmer, one of two public trustees for Social Security and Medicare, called it ''wrong to say Medicare will go broke,'' adding that the situation was ''not as dire as headlines would have you believe.''

headline.main: Chicken Little Is Ready for Medicare

docs.abstract: Fred Brock column clarifies distorted warnings that Medicare could go broke by 2019; Medicare trustees say hospital insurance trust fund is now expected to exhaust its surplus by 2019, but will still be able to pay 80 percent of its bills from Medicare payroll tax; Medicare Part B, which pays for doctors bills and other outpatient services, would not be affected by depletion of hospital fund surplus; drawing (M)
